Review Title: Great for fast-moving, intellectually curious workers with a bias to action
Pros: - pace of innovation; ability to be very hands on in solving complex problems; high intellectual curiosity of employees; huge market opportunity
Cons: - oftentimes juggling too many responsibilities with limited process to triage / prioritize work

Pros:
- good work-life balance, 100% remote as an AE (BDRs need to go into office in austin or san fran)
- hot industry, cyber security is more important than ever and will continue to be
Cons:
- sales department does not operate like a sales department. No in-person events, only virtual SKO. Very competitive amongst your teammates in terms of accounts (very bad for morale).
- the pricing structure is insanely horrible. Most deals are lost due to self-serve plans. Cloudflare offers too much for free/very cheap.
- the only successful reps (hitting at least 80% of quota) are the tenured ones who have been here 3+ years.
- upper management doesn't listen to reps when we give feedback regarding our organization and our pricing structure. Marc Boroditsky the new CRO tells salespeople to "get over it" and "learn how to sell better" and "our pricing structure will not change". It's extremely discouraging

Pros: Great product line that addresses a wide variety of network security use cases.
Cons:
Many components of the platform do not perform as well as competitors and its priced higher than comparable solutions. Also many of the important facets of the product can be purchased monthly for cheap, or completely free. This makes is much harder to sell Enterprise plans to a large portion of mid-market customers.

The sales organization segmented nearly 3 times in a one year span. The ripple effect of these changes caused disruption in sales cycles and pipeline generation for the AE and BDR organization.

Sales leadership pulled back on tech resources, tools, and updated marketing collateral which reflects the company’s overall attitude towards enabling and coaching ICs. There’s not much of a focus on proper enablement on products - too many fires to put out and all suggestions fall on deaf ears.

Pros:
* Core L7 Security Solutions and L3/L4 & L7 DDoS Technology is solid and customers like it.
* ESPP
* Unlimited PTO
Cons:
* Executive and Sales Executive Leadership lead by fear and pushes it down to the national and regional VP's. 
*CEO does not support sales or marketing employees. The morale is at an all time low after an earnings call where the CEO lambasted all the sales employees. 
*CRO is spreadsheet driven and does not understand that the sales cycles are complex and can range from 6 to 12 months. 
* Sales employees being put on PIP's just after 6 months. Again, leadership by fear. 
* Weak sales leadership is causing an extremely disorganized sales structure and bad moral. 
* Sales employees are allowed to poach other accounts and get away with it. 
* No sales accelerators. Commission is paid quarterly. Targets are set very high and practically impossible to meet/achieve. 
* Many products are not customer ready and don't have all the features that many customers are looking for. 
* No partnerships or alliances with any other vendors. Cloudflare competes with many if not all the other vendors and major public cloud providers. 
*Cloudflare is primarily an engineering driven company. This may sound great, but when you are in sales, it can be very hard to sell solutions without good marketing support.

Review Title: Horrible executive leadership, needs to grow up
Pros:
None anymore, good people either have left or been let go.

If you got lucky and sold your stock during it's the peak in 2021, congratulations. Check out the public insider activity and remember these are the same people who decided to gut the health insurance and cut headcount.
Cons: Moody CEO yells, drinks, and cries in meetings, publicly embarrasses his own Sales org, and perpetuates a culture where the entire executive and management team points blame at others (including each other) for company shortfalls. Mass PIP's are being used to reduce headcount while CEO constantly bragged about not doing layoffs during the pandemic. The air is thick with anxiety, wondering who will disappear next.

Pros: Nothing to be honest sorry
Cons: CEO is a coward. Google viral cloudflare video if you’re confused. They laid off all my peers who were great performers for no reason and they will do the same to you. Run far away. Many of our competitors will treat you better. I’m trying to get out while I can. Horrified by HR and leadership. And I’ve worked and Amazon and Salesforce.

Pros:
- Great hands on experience with systems at massive scale
- Interesting and challenging engineering problems
- Always working on exciting impactful work, never gets old
- Everyone is pretty friendly overall
- Fully remote, with freedom to work out of any of their offices around the world

I really feel thankful for getting the opportunity to work at a company making such a huge impact to the everyday world and internet at large
Cons:
- Compensation seems like it could be much better
- No 401k match
- No on-call overtime pay (even on holidays)
- Can be hard to get work across finish line on time as every team has slightly different process

Review Title: It’s an alright place to work.
Pros:
Never seen layoffs for technical employees. 

Exciting technologies

Remote friendly 

Good office buildings

Extreme levels of transparency

Talented people
Cons:
Overly-complicated and long interview process and onboarding leads to hiring difficulties

Salary is based on where you live in USA so you are punished for living in cheaper states

Middle management bloat

Pros: The teams are full of hardworking individuals and direct managers. The product is good
Cons:
I didn't want to interview when I saw previous Glassdoor reviews and the CEO's statement on the 2023 earnings call. I decided to trust that things would be different and was told the same during my interview, however I should have listened to my gut.

There's not much to be said that hasn't been already. It's a competition and the people who are still there were either demoted or got smaller territories. Senior leadership doesn't listen and you are just a number to them. The product is hard to sell when a lot of the solutions are given for so cheap.

Review Title: Toxicity seems to be rewarded here
Pros:
- Lots of impressively smart, educated and experienced people
- Lots of innovation and future-thinking
- Remote work is genuine and allows for work-life balance

Note: I left voluntarily and on good terms.
Cons:
- Virtually no career paths
- Zero employee review process with feedback from management
- Lacks: tuition reimbursement, 401k matching, wellness funds
- Promotes people to management who cause chaos and are generally abusive
- Finger-pointing and deflecting blame is common practice
- Nerd bullies are beloved and rewarded
- CEO is rather emotional and moody
- Total chaos overall

Tech culture (especially in engineering) is already tough enough but this place seems to be reversing course with all of the improvements people have been striving to achieve over the years.

Pros: Good product. Some good people.
Cons:
Where to begin? 

-Territories are assigned with absolutely no thought process behind them. How your territory performs is truly luck of the draw. You will also get accounts taken out of your territory with little to no notice. 
-There is no incentive to build long lasting relationships with your customers due to this. Instead there is a mentality of close whatever you can while you can. 
-There is no CSM/CSE aligned to any of your accounts. They all use a pool model. Customers hate the support system and complain that they get rude replies or it takes them weeks to get a response. On top of that, many CSEs are overworked and overbooked. 
-In Mid Market, you will be working with 20 different SE's, just depending on which one is assigned to which account of yours. You have to prep each SE for every customer call you invite them to. Many SE's are not seasoned - they have very low sales skills and rely on you completely as the AE to tell them when to speak. They have no curiosity to help find out more about the customers problems. You'll be lucky if they don't hinder the process, never mind help move it along. 
-If a partner brings a deal to Cloudflare, that customer is locked in with that partner forever. As a sales person you are de-incentivized from moving the customer to a different partner or moving them direct (even if it is what the customer directly asks for). This creates partner relationships where the partner can coast and add no value, yet still make their margin on upsells when the AE does all the work. It also creates dissatisfaction with the customer as they feel they're overpaying for partner services for nothing in return. 
-Sales reps are required to handle renewals even though they do not get paid for them. God forbid you need to make changes to the renewals or the customer wants to downgrade some of their services; internal processes make that incredibly difficult and complex. 
-You can pretty much make pricing anything you want it to be as a rep, which means customers are left confused on what pricing they can expect. One rep may extend a discount of 70% to a customer, and that will be the expectation when they are moved to a different rep even years down the line, creating dissatisfaction and lack of trust with the new rep that can no longer get that high of a discount approved. 
-Customers complain of lack of visibility/transparency when it comes to pricing. 
-Managers are hit/miss but overall I've noticed they are not very experienced, have not seen best practices at other companies, and aren't super helpful in advocating for their reps. 
-Layoffs for no defendable reason, letting go talented reps who haven't even gotten a chance to fully ramp and who receive positive feedback in performance reviews
-You may get hired for one role and in 6 months be told you're covering a completely different patch and type of customer
-Pay is below average
-Severance for layoffs is extremely minimal 
-no 401k match
-rising costs for the healthcare plans
-CEO is toxic, inexperienced in building strong sales organizations/processes, and regularly belittles sales org
-Many folks have left due to questionable unethical business practices, management issues, favoritism, and other worse issues... It is a widespread issue across all geographies and teams.

It is such a shame because the Cloudflare product line is incredible and the company has so much potential. But currently there are just too many issues that cannot be ignored.

Pros: Product is fantastic, industry leader in many areas.
Cons: Sales ROE is constantly changing, you could be hired with the expectation of being in one market and then within 6 months that changes. The worst part is inconsistent firing of sales reps. Even reps who hit quota for two consecutive quarters were not immune to latest release. And severance pathetic, even for folks that worked for over 7 years with the company. There is no performance that is "safe", which leads to an unhealthy working environment.

Review Title: Great place to work but making a lot of changes internally to the sales team
Pros:
- Great company culture 
- Great people surrounding you
- Benefits are good
Cons:
- Steep learning curve if you don't come from this background
- Not a lot of good feedback from manager
- Company is going through a re-org and internal changes

Pros: Around half of my colleagues were kind and hardworking
Cons: Very little career opportunities due to unclear promotion process, overworked for low pay, toxic executives pushing unrealistic deadlines leading to overwork and scaring people when unrealistic deadlines were not met

Pros: Working opportunity to make money working from home
Cons: This company is a death trap do not come here. The leadership is trash and don’t know how to actually lead teams. There is no opportunity for career advancement. They like to pitch this beautiful empathetic workplace which is completely false. The job you are hired for might not be the one they pigeon hole you into. They breed a toxic hostile environment and don’t do anything to fix it. The CEO and COO are currently being sued by a board member for blackmail to get more shares. The CSO is currently being sued by the federal government for fraud from his time at Uber. They expect you to have no life and work all the time. Need I say more.

Pros: The product is pretty good.
Cons: No 401 Match, No learning and career development

Review Title: Cloudflare is asleep at the wheel on the sales front
Pros:
- The product and people are amazing! Such potential here...
- A COO that is truly the glue here - great human.
-
Cons:
- The CEO's ego and lack of respect for his sales organziation will impede this companies growth and ensure they are built out as a well oiled machine. 

- They hire and fire without any true effort into their sales people (outside of low priced sales training that does not even apply to the process it takes to sale here). Literally burn money on a hire with irrational ramp periods and set unattainable bars to rip and replace with the exact same type of rep (has to be expensive this way).

- A seriously scary feeling of not knowing what they are doing with the sales org, and panic fixing it without any accountability to the failing pricing structure and overall structure.

Review Title: Nice company with room for growth
Pros: - competitive base salary - good tech - lots of room for exponential customer growth - fresh ideas that challenge the status quo are welcome
Cons: - equity is low - no bonuses - no 401K match - no budget for events or travel

Review Title: You Are Set Up To Fail Within The Sales Org
Pros: - Great Product and benefits.
Cons:
The morale at CF has been in the gutter since the CEO publicly shamed the sales org last year & with the 2024 layoffs. Alongside the consistent fear of wondering if this is going to be your last day at your job, the sales ops and processes behind the scenes are some of the worst I've seen in all of the tech space. For each deal, you spend more time processing a deal than actually being customer-facing. The leadership team said they were aware of the issue and were going to focus on simplifying the process, but it's gotten much, much worse. 

Along with the layoffs in 2024, I have heard that BDR's who got promoted to AE beginning of Q4 were also let go. They had little to no training in the role & with an average sales cycle of over 6 months, it is almost impossible to hit their number, let alone get established in the role. Also, BDR team leads were demoted to BDR's, and AE managers were demoted to AE. 

During my tenure, I have NEVER SEEN executive leadership or the CRO chat with any of the immediate sales team or gain first-hand insights from individual reps on what's working and what's not. It's quite pathetic, to be honest. Ethier the CEO, COO, or CRO chooses to be ignorant of how much of a mess the SalesOrg is or just not care because they don't believe in sales in general. Plus, I have also never seen so many reps who were quota crushers at their previous company struggle to hit even 30% of their number. 99% of reps are great sellers, and greater people of character, but the sales culture is so much of a mess that you are not enabled to do your best work. 

And, when you cut INCREDIBLE SALES folks who have been within the Cloudflare culture and who have taught other new sales folk how to do your job, the employees that you will replace will have even a GREATER CHALLENGE to their role, causing even more issues. Has any of this been properly thought out?! 

Bottom line- You are set up to fail within the CF sales org. When the CEO takes pride pubically in individually hand-crafting and sending offer letters to every single new employee, there is also a weight of responsibility of taking accountability for your actions when you don't provide teams the culture and foundation to do their best work. I hope that executive leadership sees the challenges FIRST HAND within the sales org & acts fast, or it's going to be more "putting lipstick on a pig" and wondering why things aren't getting better.

Pros: Good income and relaxed workspace
Cons: Layoffs suck and cloudflare recently did them.

Pros: Total compensation, WFH flexibility, supportive managers, intelligent and compassionate coworkers, transparent and accessible executives.
Cons: No 401k matching or bonuses, recent shift in healthcare plan that is lower quality then previous plan.

Pros: Awesome office. Fun place to be while you are there.
Cons: They move you around on teams and do not set you up for success. No re-training when going from one roll to another. Throw you on a PIP, tell you that your not going to be fired and everything will be ok, then you no longer have a job.

Pros:

Portfolio is too extensive

Pros: Flexible, great colleagues and work culture. You learn something new everyday. There is never a dull day at CF

Pros: Good product, decent leadership, bright future

Review Title: Strong Product, Fear Based Sales Culture, Elitist CEO, Robotic CRO
Pros: Cloudflare's products are second to none. I'll stand behind that. They are the best cybersecurity company from a complete product standpoint.
Cons: Where to start. Operations is an absolute disaster. Sales Management doesn't know what they're doing and simply push a "sell or get out" attitude. It's sad too because I saw the culture change over time. When I started there was a "lead with empathy" attitude by everyone. Now, and especially since new CRO Marc Boroditsky came in, it's much more fear based and robotic. Marc began subtly reducing AE's compensations in sneaky ways and certainly got the ball rolling for Matthew's embarrassing Q1 '23 earnings call where he literally called all of his success from the last 10 years solely because of the strength of the product (Matthew doesn't care about sales people at all FYI). I'm happy to have worked there while I did but the shift in company culture is abhorrently trending in the wrong direction.

Pros: good job if you don's live in an expensive city
Cons: repetitive nature of the work

Review Title: Great product, fast rate of change
Pros: Opportunities for exposure & internal growth
Cons: Constant change, low confidence from executives in revenue team

Pros: Great, fast moving product and brand recognition. Intelligent coworkers.
Cons:
The company is designed from the ground up to push customers and incentivizes them to stay there rather than transition to enterprise. 

Little to no investment in sales process, or data so ops has no idea what makes a good account. 

Brutal sales culture with no manager discretion on firing.

Pros: There is nothing good except the technology
Cons:
Management 
Tools 
Training
Hostile environment 
Zero senior level support

Pros:
- No accountability for performance, it's extremely easy to coast and just barely meet status quo, conversely it's hard to get raise or promotion unless your management chain drives hard to make it happen (unfortunately there are a lot of incompetent engineering managers at CF)
- Unlimited PTO goes well with zero accountability culture
Cons:
First thing I need to highlight is the engineering culture is highly toxic, during my time at CF, I've encountered the following:
- High confrontation (getting yelled at publicly in meetings, getting massive downvotes and negative emojis in chat threads when folks don't agree with you, lack of respect for people as humans)
- Gaslighting (after raising concerns about a teammate's behavior towards me in meetings and code reviews, manager literally just responded with "don't take it personally, they're just trying to attack the problem" - classic tiptoeing response to avoid addressing respect and empathy)
- No concept of "disagreeing and committing", a lot of engineers at CF are smart, but are jerks. There's a lot of folks who are credible in terms of their individual talent, but certainly are not likeable. When a decision has been made, instead of respecting and committing to the decision, I've seen and was horrified by the unprofessionalism directed towards the decision makers.

Another big problem that I've experienced that continues to be an issue at CF is lack of valuing employees:
- Low compensation (I made it a big concern that I was not fairly compensated, especially when CF's stock plummeted, I made a case that I could literally go anywhere else and have my TC doubled, I was told off both by my management chain and by HR, so guess what? I interviewed and found a new role that doubled my TC.)
- Deceit (a huge red flag when I initially joined was that the recruiter I was working with flat out lied about how he didn't know what my level will be when I joined, he also mumbled something along the lines of "we don't do levels at CF" - this was downright false, and I was brought in a P3, when the level that matched my experience was supposed to be P4)

Unless you're particularly excited about CF's mission, I would avoid at all costs. Even if I didn't receive another offer, I would have needed to leave soon since my mental health was deteriorating based on what I experienced above.

Review Title: Could have been so much better.
Pros: Product is amazing, I use it at home for personal use. Their whole suite is master class stuff.
Cons: Volatile C-Suite and shaky leadership, Plus always changing processes and teams is tough.

Pros: Great product. They work. They are next-gen

Review Title: Solid place to work at but micro managing has become a thing
Pros: Austin office is brand new and super nice (5 stories) in the middle of East Austin. The job can be good depending on who your manager is and how good they are at selling/managing.
Cons: 1) Mid -Market got broken into two (commercial and digital native emerging), which has made it much harder for an individual to pick up solid accounts since the pool size has shrunk. 2) AE's that have been here for a while have all the good accounts, so new reps are stuck with what's left. 3) We often lose deals to our Self-Service plans since most of our tools people can get free or for $25 or $250 a month. 4) We sell way too many technical solutions. Hard to get familiar with all of them.

Pros: The only pro I have is leaving this company
Cons: They laid ton’s of people off for “performance” which was out of no where. Managers reporting good performance, HR says bad performance and boom let go.

Pros:
- remote work
- nice team members
- work matters
Cons:
- no 401k match
- volatile benefits

Pros: Everyone n everything are amazing
Cons: Nothing is con in a company like this

Pros: the solutions are very internet related and technology oriented .
Cons:
it has a toxic working environment.
leadership believes they can predict the future of an employee in 15 minutes .
CEO is rude and controls the board and all decisions in the company .

Pros: - Great product and industry - Benefits are amazing - Hybrid/Remote - Decent Base Salary (50k-55k) - RSU's (Starting is about 15-20k vested through 4 years) - Great Tech Stack (ZoomInfo, Intricately, 6Sense, Salesforce)
Cons: - No work-life balance (Most reps hitting/ exceeding quota are putting in nearly 60+ hours a week) - During this review, Cloudflare is "trimming the fat," so many BDR positions are available. - Initial promises of progression into AE role in 90 Days, but leadership added into the fine print that it will be 18 months. (Not guaranteed either, most AE's are external hires.) - OTE is 75-80k, but as mentioned previously, they are moving into a churn-and-burn business model with their AE's and BDR's. OTE is next to unachievable, which is already low in compensation. - Management isn't the best in leadership and providing training and guidance, leading to many BDRs & AE's losing their jobs. - Horrible restructurings each quarter. Q1, they started pushing a territory model in which most BDRs weren't given accounts/territory until the middle of Q1, leaving a month and a half to hit an entire quota. - Same issue into Q2, poor implementations of Salesloft with little to no help getting onboarded but still expected to hit a full quota, which had also increased drastically. They were realigning and refining territories into Q2 & Q3 as well. - Matthew (CEO speaks poorly of Sales reps and accounts all success to the great product. He went public with this message and announced that because of this, they are laying off the majority of AE's, which also didn't help the BDRs. This left some reps with little to no accounts to work once again. - No one knows what's going on in the org, which may just be how it is in corporate America, but you would expect better for a company as "established" as Cloudflare. This leads to issues with management, as mentioned previously, and poor executions of restructuring and software implementations. - I can't recommend any Sales roles from Cloudflare to anyone now. Hopefully, that will change as new leadership emerges in the next couple of years. - Also, Nepotism is a big thing here.

Pros: remote work options and high pay
Cons: Difficult to move upwards in company

Review Title: Great Product, Poor culture and poor Sales Leadership

Pros: Culture is awesome. Everyone cares for eachother and your team will typically do their best to put you in a position to succeed.

Review Title: Great technical products. Terrible sales management leadership
Pros: Great technical environment for developers and engineers Great products Great coworkers
Cons: Company culture has deteriorated rapidly in the past 6 months becoming very toxic...curiously about the same time as Black Rock increased their position in Cloudflare. Micromanagement style in the sales org. Sales leadership is some of the worst I have ever seen. They don't seem to have any long or medium term vision. Constant reorgs without proper implementation plans. Don't expect salary compensation adjustments to reflect cost of living increases or inflation. Sales quotas however seem to grow linearly even in economic downturn. So the longer you stay at Cloudflare the less you make over time and the more you have to work to achieve the same bonus level.

Review Title: Look up the CEO rant, Toxic, does business with groups who attract hackers
Pros: The fish stinks from the head. This is a toxic work culture in terms of the sales org and the top down leadership. Forecasting calls don’t seem to be meant to assist / mentor, it’s an opportunity to put people down and that attitude permeates to anyone with even a modicum of power.
Cons: The CEO trashed his own people and then fired them, instead of firing the people who hired them and attracting better leadership. Also this company does business with anyone who will pay. So that makes this company a target for DDoS attacks, Anonymous, hackers, etc.

Pros: Collaborative Sexy products Values and expects you to offer your opinions Supportive leadership
Cons: Growing pains are real Needs better benefits package Performance feedback needs improvement

Review Title: Decent Company, but CEO Hates Salespeople
Pros: -Solid brand name because of the free plan -Company's Layer 7 services are some of the best out there -High base salary
Cons: "This is a JV sales org" - one of my first managers. -Territories are still super vague; expect to spend a ton of time hunting for and fighting over accounts. I can't stress enough how much of your time this will eat -THE FREE PLAN. The company gives away like 60% of its best stuff for free. This kills an unreal amount of deals. Not only do you have to sell to companies that are down in this economy (crypto, VC-funded SaaS), you have to compete against yourself. Matthew Prince dislikes salespeople and that attitude filters down. -Almost no training; 3 months of boot camp that doesn't resemble the job, at all. Management just tells you "send more emails." I'm not exaggerating. The sales org worked in a bull economy, and now almost zero pipe is being generated because their methodologies don't actually work. Zero in-seat training. -Sales ops team is like one person. If you need any help building out reports, etc, you're on your own -Company pushes you to generate 4x pipeline which is comically unrealistic, especially in Digital Native, which has been wrecked by the economy -Some of the senior managers couldn't sell water in a desert. They expanded pretty aggressively when times were good, and took some real stragglers. Managers have no idea how to generate more pipe. Nobody does. This company got by in a bull economy and now they're struggling -I've worked at other publicly traded cybersecurity companies, and the sales org here is a flat out joke compared to others. You're completely on your own, start to finish.

Review Title: Great technology and culture, poor GTM execution
Pros: The people and products have consistently been one of Cloudflare's greatest assets. I've had great mentorship while working there, and there is fluid career mobility. The product portfolio has continued to grow at a rapid pace, and there is always more to learn. TAM is massive and the industry is exciting.
Cons: Leadership has not prioritized resourcing for GTM teams. New sales reps would go months without access to basic tools (e.g. Sales Navigator), lengthening their ramp time and hampering enablement efforts. Pipeline and demand generation best practices are still very immature for a company of this size.

Review Title: Smart People / Poor Management / No Career Track
Pros: You will work with some amazing people.
Cons: No salary raises - Paid in stock, which raises your tax bill Non-sales teams see no career growth Managers are outside hires or are the least qualified promotions High Turnover / Toxic workplace / DEI is non-Existent

Pros: I had the pleasure of working with some terrific people, and their products really are great. However…
Cons: The CEO has no regard/ respect for Sales. Don’t take my word for it. Read the call transcript from the Q1 earnings call where he says that in good times salespeople are just order takers and in bad times “we get to see who isn’t wearing any shorts”. This was his excuse for cutting 100 people from the org, while touting 37% year over year growth in Q1. I think the motivation was to pay shareholders a dividend and himself a fat bonus. Unless you see 100 new open requisitions posted in the next 90 days, this was in fact a layoff. Just days before being cut I was reassured that my position was secure. I wasn’t even on a Formal PIP. In my time here there were ever changing ROEs, they took away essential clarity and removed incentives, and at one point the team spent 6 months without guidance on which accounts were even ours to work. Then they blame the reps for a dip in performance. It’s poor leadership on a grand scale and they have no idea how to run a best in class channel sales organization.

Review Title: Base salary not competitive, Hard to get promoted
Pros: Great company as far as vision, product and growth potential. Unlimited PTO, remote work, flexible schedule. Great entry company to get into the cybersecurity niche industry.
Cons: However salary ranges are low for the tech sector. As a BDR you are required to hit 3 quarters of fully ramped quota before any promotion. So a BDR will be in the role for at least 12 -15 months at a minimum which is a long time in a very hard and demanding job. The work is not pleasant and has little gratification. With a tight economy, it has been hard for at least 50% BDRs to hit quota lately.

Review Title: Sales Team Needs Help and Is Not Supported By upper Management
Pros: high base salary, great co-workers, good products
Cons: CEO doesn't believe in sales org because he thinks his products sell themselves. Lot's of changes being made constantly to book of accounts, ROE, and accounts that you have made progress on get taken away, pipeline further than a quarter out is discouraged and is not considered an opportunity, No clear, consistent sales strategy, over 60% of reps not hitting quota, they give too much away on self serve plans to sell to mid market customers. There are days you will not leave your desk.

Pros: I enjoy working with people at Cloudflare
Cons: Work can be very busy

Review Title: Work hard and take advantage of many resources
Pros: Great resources, mostly good team players with a handful of people that are difficult to work with. You get what you put in as far as working hard and seeking out resources. Don’t expect to have your hand held but if you ask for help proactively you will do very well.
Cons: Work life balance can be a challenge with working from home and very demanding goals. Lots of new processes have been put in place that have helped make working here a lot better than when I started. Major con is a very rigid promotion schedule.

Pros: Good leadership Good pay Good work life balance Unlimited PTO
Cons: Some workflows need fine tuning or aren't as organized.

Pros: I really enjoyed my time at Cloudflare. It was a transitional time for me but I learned a lot from the team and processes.
Cons: Difficulty learning and ramping unless you take it upon yourself to dig deep and ask questions. It will help if you come from a similar industry but still doable if you have passion and desire to learn.

Review Title: May not be great but definitely has lot of promise
Pros: 1. Company has lot of promise and lot of potential 2. CEO and COO are passionate leaders 3. Lot to deliver in the company
Cons: 1. Middle Management has to learn to deliver 2. Lot of redundancy in roles 3. Middle management can't execute 4. Salary wise can get better 5. No 401 matching 6. Growth path is unclear for people working hard

Pros: Technology is solid and customers like it Equity could be valuable one day if you get in now Unlimited vacation Great health benefits
Cons: CRO changed the comp plans in FY23 at the same time goals were hiked up and folks lost a lot of accounts- recipe for disaster. There's constant fighting over accounts between reps and leadership. Morale is an all time low after CEO earnings call where he lambasted sales teams. Everyone operating based on fear Very little accountability from leadership- they just push the fear down the chain and squeeze everyone Company doesn't prioritize the channel so diminishes its effectiveness and will not grow at the rate it hopes without leveraging it as a force multiplier Extremely toxic work environment- people are publically humiliated regularly Unlimited vacation BUT don't expect to be truly off the job at any time

Pros: Growing company with lots to sale.
Cons: The internal processes are broken.

Pros: - A bunch of talented and curious individuals. Very collaborative working environment
Cons: - No 401k match. - Pay is average - Prefer to stay short-staffed and overwork employees versus hiring more staff

Pros: Culture of willing to help build a better internet
Cons: Salary not at par with the industry

Pros: -rapidly innovating their services and offerings -the end customer usually loves the platform and it's powerful yet simple
Cons: -leadership was late to transition from a free for all model into a structured territory model which is causing a lot of growing pains -there is a lot of confusion on pricing skews, support levels, and general product offering. (bundles and packages aren't clear) -you often have to sell against the free/pro/bus plans which offer an incredible amount at a fraction of the cost -underdeveloped channel partnerships -SEs aren't aligned to territories so it's hard to develop a working relationship and be strategic with accounts on a technical level.

Pros: You will definitely be working with some of the most talented salespeople here
Cons:
Leadership does not support sales, which leads to the following: 
- Salespeople are expected to do a lot with very little support. No relevant training, the training we do receive on products are useless because they just give away majority of features for "freemium low prices", and are proud of that, but still expect sales to sell the extra expensive Enterprise version of everything. 
- Does not take responsibility when not hitting sales targets, but plays the typical blame sales game, instead of focusing on differentiating product and pricing strategies. 
- The pricing model is unclear, and no one can explain to me how it really works.
Conclusion: Sales beware

Pros: Talented colleagues, previously a great culture, which is now sadly a thing of the past.
Cons: Payis below average. Comp plans and quotas are woeful. CF are struggling in the downturn. The CEO detests sales, he publicly berates us and our teams and is of the opinion that the portfolio can / should be able to sell itself. (See Q1FY23 Earnings call transcript). Shameful.

Pros: Great team and company that cares about their employees
Cons: Nothing to say as of now

Pros: Company is innovator in security and networking space
Cons: Growing fast can cause growing pains

Pros: great product direct competition from self-serve offerings unorganized sales org but opportunity to make big $ with hard work and luck
Cons: c level blame everything on sales

Pros: Good people Great product Secure industry
Cons: Growing pains No 401k matching

Pros: Fast-paced culture / good manager (for me specifically) / good team mates
Cons: Cross-functional efforts are strained even when teams are aligned

Review Title: Great Culture and Interesting Problems to Solve
Pros: As a contender in many of the spaces it is trying to compete, you'll be in a position to innovate and build products from the ground up. Teams and lean, bureaucracy is minimal, and your colleagues are motivated.
Cons: Internal tools and automation are not on the same level as you would expect from the tech giants. Management structure can be unclear. Hard to fill headcount when FAANGs are willing to pay more.

Review Title: Nice, smart people working on interesting problems
Pros: Very positive culture and competent management. Reasonable work/life balance working on interesting problems.
Cons: Being remote, it's tough to branch out and meet everyone.

Review Title: Amazing company/products, sales org a mess
Pros:
- Great company 
- Great leadership 
- Great products (upper right on Gartner) with constant improvement 
- Lots of products, expanding to zero trust which is big for the future 
- Finally split into territories/segments in mid-market 
- PTO seems flexible
Cons:
- Only just got territories for mid-market (12 year old company) 
- Transition to territories/segments has been rocky 
- Sales org tries to reinvent the wheel (hence no territories until recently), does not use best practices and makes it hard on themselves for no reason 
- Unorganized 
- Poor middle management/sales management 
- No 401k match 
- ESPP has 1 year hold 
- More of a product-led org than sales-led (CEO does not like sales people)
- BDR org has extremely low standards. No cold calling, they do not even CALL leads, they will just email. Don't qualify their own opps, they just get a reply and let AE qualify with prospect. They're not hungry to get opps or even close deals
- Sales commission paid out quarterly, 45 days after EOQ

Pros: Great co-workers Good products Good pay at the time
Cons: Declining Culture Idiot CRO Managers are useless Career progression is a coin flip Awful Marketing/MQL inflow

Pros: Amazing product and Technical team
Cons: Unessessary and harsh leadership pressure

Review Title: Right People and Trajectory, Sales org weird
Pros:
- Great technology, incredible vision for market
- Smart, impressive people everywhere
- Sales management understands sales org problems and is patient with new hire struggles
- Constant updates/investments for products
- United Healthcare paid for
- RSUs and ESPP should pay off in future
- Way happier here than last company
Cons:
- Sales org is messed up generally (low standards of salesforce hygiene, many people lazy in terms of activity), probably more so to so much scaling/growth
- No territories today (you could work accounts in California or Vermont) and you have to find YOUR OWN accounts, start book from SCRATCH
- Lots of confusion/conflict with ROE due to lack of territories
- Constant struggle to find (even sometimes to keep) accounts
- Due to above, difficult first 12-18 months for new hires
- More of a product-led org than sales-led (CEO does not like sales people)
- BDR org has extremely low standards. No cold calling, they do not even CALL leads, they will just email. Don't qualify their own opps, they just get a reply and let AE qualify with prospect. They're not hungry to get opps or even close deals
- No 401k match
- OFFICE FIRST company (weird about remote) but that is changing finally

Pros: nice people, learning focused culture, fast paced, great business goals and leadership communication
Cons: shedding some startup habits have to strongly advocate for your work life balance boundaries

Pros: Loved it, good team atmosphere
Cons: Not much, company doing great

Pros: Good products. Good Coworkers. Good Leads and managers. Good inclusive culture for individual contributors.
Cons: Disorganized sales leadership vision. BDR leadership unorganized. Disconnect from higher leadership, and whats actually going on. Changing promotion requirements. Low amount of reps hitting quota or even getting to 80%. Lack of diversity in leadership, especially since they pride themselves in diversity.

Pros: Terrific product and innovation. They always seem to be releasing excellent updates that customers actually find valuable. It's definitely a must have product.
Cons: The sales org could be a lot stronger. There are no territories or sets of accounts. It's considered "Wild West". There are also about 20+ different SKUs you're responsible for selling and it's all highly technical. This leads to a steep learning curve. Lastly, there's no Gong/Chorus, no 401k match, no unified sales methodology, no learning reimbursements . If it wasn't for the great product, I don't know where CF would be.

Review Title: great place to learn and grow
Pros: great place to learn and grow but you must grind and be smart - no dummies
Cons: lots of product and lots of competetion with other AEs

Review Title: Great company but moving toward from startup environment to corporate culture
Pros: Great product suite along with great talent
Cons: Noticeable change from startup environment to corporate culture

Review Title: Great place to be, with some growing pains as they transition to being a large company.
Pros: Great people, and fantastic management. It's been a long time since I've had a great boss, and I'm very grateful for that!
Cons:
Soon we will have geographic territories. So far has been a bit confusing/ frustrating without assigned accounts, and with sales reps often having to fight to keep the deals they do find. But, this will be remedied soon, and will allow us to improve our alignment with the Channel.

Commissions are currently paid 45 days after the close of the quarter, as opposed to monthly, which is a bit atypical for the industry. It's a long time to wait for commissions when most companies pay the month after a deal is signed.

Pros: Great people Full transparency Positive culture Great time off policy
Cons: Low budget and pay compared to other tech No 401k match
